components.label: HTML
components.content:
Label Buster

Label Buster is a step-by-step guide to help you identify information you need to create a food label that meets Australian requirements. At the end of Label Buster, you will generate:

  • a product sheet you can give to a printer to design a label for you
  • an example of what your food label should look like.

The Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (the Food Standards Code) sets the standards for food labelling in Australia. Significant penalties apply in Queensland under the Food Act 2006 (the Act), for non-compliance with the Food Standards Code.

Did you know

Labels must have the same information whether you sell your product once at a market stall, or regularly to a supermarket.

Who can use Label Buster?

Label Buster is designed for small to medium food businesses. If your food has complex labelling requirements, such as infant formula, sports supplements or alcohol, the tool does not provide all the information you need, and you are recommended to seek professional legal advice from a food labelling consultant.

Before you start

To use Label Buster, you will need:

Up to 1 hour - if you are familiar with food labelling requirements.

Up to 2 hours - if you have never made a food label before.

You will need information about your food, such as:

  • ingredients
  • use-by or best-before dates
  • any storage conditions or directions for use

The questions marked with a * must be completed. Other questions are optional.

Did you know

Label Buster will provide you with food labelling information to help you to comply with the Food Standards Code. After you finish Label Buster, you will need to include other mandatory requirements for a Nutrition Information Panel , weights and measures , and Country of origin labelling. Health Star Rating is a voluntary scheme you can choose to add to your food.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Terms of use

Please read and accept the terms of use before using Label Buster

  • Terms and conditions
  • Privacy statement
  • Disclaimer
  • Copyright

Warning

This tool does not meet all your legislative requirements, only those relating to the Food Standards Code. You will need to include other requirements on your food label, such as country of origin labelling.

It is your responsibility to ensure all the information on your food label is true and correct.

Queensland Health respects your right to privacy in using Label Buster. Any information you give will be handled by Queensland Health in accordance with the Information Privacy Act 2009.

No personal information is stored when you use Label Buster. For information about how Queensland Health protects your personal information, or to learn about your right to access your personal information, please see out website at www.health.qld.gov.au

Please note that our terms of use may change over time.

Label Buster is current as of June 2020 and shows information up to and including amendment number 192 of the Food Standards Code. It is recommended that you refer to the most current version of the Food Standards Code for full details and note any changes.

Your use of this website is your agreement to our terms and conditions.

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Label Buster
HTML
components.content:
About food labels

Select on the food label sections below to learn about labels.

|

Food labels must show the name of the food to help identify the food.

The name and description of the food must reflect its true nature. For example, strawberry yoghurt must contain strawberries. If the yoghurt contained strawberry flavouring rather than real fruit, then the name would need to indicate that it is strawberry-flavoured yoghurt.

If the name of the food does not reflect its true nature, then you must include a description of the true nature on the label. For example, Luke’s Hot’s Sauce (red chilli pepper sauce).

To help customers identify where food has come from or to use for a food recall when food is unsafe, a food label must include the following business details:

  • name of the business supplying the food
  • business address in Australia or New Zealand, or a description of the location, of the premises where the business is being operated. A postal address cannot be used.

The National Measurement Institute is responsible for making sure food is measured and weighed correctly, and that the food is labelled with the correct weight and unit.

For example, food labelled as being 500g should weigh 500g and use the metric system of grams (g), kilograms (kg), millilitres (mL), litres (L), etc.

Visit the NMI website for more information on how to comply with the laws around weights and other measures.

Food packaged with a shelf life of 2 years or less must show a date mark.

Foods that should be eaten before a certain date for health and safety reasons must be labelled with a use-by date. Otherwise, a best-before date is required if the food has a shelf life of less than 2 years. Although it may be safe to eat the food after the best-before date, the food may have lost quality or some nutritional value.

Bread with a shelf-life of less than 7 days, can use a baked-for date or baked-on date instead of a best-before date.

The lot identification means a number or other information that identifies where the food was made and the batch it was part of. Often the date mark, name and address of the manufacturer meets this requirement.

Storage conditions
To keep food until its best-before or use-by date include storage conditions on your label.

Directions for use
A food label must have directions on how to use or prepare the food if needed for health and safety reasons.

A food label must contain a list of ingredients. The Food Standards Code has rules that describe how each ingredient must be listed, what it is called, and how it is formatted.

To help consumers avoid foods that are not safe for them to eat due to health conditions they may have, the Food Standards Code lists mandatory advisory statements, warning statements and allergen declarations that must be shown on a food label depending on the type of food and its ingredients.

The nutrition information panel (NIP) shows the number of servings in the package and the average amounts in a serving of food and per 100 grams (or 100 millilitres) of food for:

  • energy (in kilojoules)
  • protein
  • fat (including saturated fat)
  • carbohydrates (including sugars)
  • sodium

If a nutrition, health or related claim is made, the NIP must also show the amount of nutrient or substance. For example: the amount of calcium must be shown in the nutrition information panel if a claim about calcium is made.

There are strict requirements about claims that can be made and how they should be written on a label.

Nutrition content claims are claims about the content of certain nutrients or substances in a food. For example, contains calcium.

Health claims refer to a relationship between food and health. For example, calcium for bone and teeth.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Label Buster exclusions (test)

Foods with complex labelling requirements are excluded from Label Buster. The following questions will help you to work out if you can use Label Buster for your food.

Is your food , a formulated caffeinated drink, an electrolyte drink or a drink made from cereals, nuts, and/or seeds?

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Ingredients

A food label must contain a list of ingredients that have been used to make the food. This is also known as the statement of ingredients.

components.legend: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (characterising ingredients)?
components.label: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (characterising ingredients)?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint">For example: strawberries in strawberry jam, meat in a meat pie.</small>

components.label: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (characterising ingredients)?
HTML
components.content:
Characterising ingredients

Food labels must show the percentage of the characterising ingredients in the food. The Food Standards Code provides details on how characterising ingredients and components should be calculated and shown.
For example: The ingredient list would show the strawberries in strawberry jam as: Strawberries (23%).

components.legend: Do you use any compound ingredients to make your food?
components.label: Do you use any compound ingredients to make your food?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  A compound ingredient is any ingredient that is made from two or more ingredients. For example: chocolate chips in a muffin, tomato paste on a pizza.
  </small>

components.label: Do you use any compound ingredients to make your food?
HTML
components.content:
Compound ingredients

If a food contains compound ingredients that contribute 5% or more to the final food, then all the ingredients and additives in that compound ingredient must be declared. If a food contains a compound ingredient that contributes less than 5% to the final food, then only allergens and food additives require listing.
For example: The ingredient list would show the dark chocolate chips in a muffin as: dark chocolate chips [sugar, cocoa mass, cocoa butter, emulsifier (soy lecithin), natural vanilla flavour]

components.legend: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an alternative ingredient to make your food?
components.label: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an alternative ingredient to make your food?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  This includes a food ingredient or additive that is replaced with another food or additive that serves the same function. 
For example: sultanas or raisins in a protein ball.

  </small>

components.label: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an alternative ingredient to make your food?
HTML
components.content:
Alternative ingredients

Alternative ingredients, including food additives, must be declared.
For example: The ingredient list would show: sultanas or raisins.

components.legend: Do you want to list an ingredient with a generic name?
components.label: Field Set
HTML
components.content:
Generic names may be used to describe the ingredient.
Cheese, cocoa butter, crystallised fruit, fruit, gum bases, herbs, meat, milk protein, poultry meat, spices and vegetables can be used as a generic name without any conditions.
Cereals, fats or oils, fish, milk solids, offal, nuts, starch, and sugar have other requirements.
For example: Apple, pear and peach listed as “fruit” in a fruit pie.

components.label: Do you want to list an ingredient with a generic name?
HTML
components.content:
Generic Names

Generic names are specified in the Food Standards Code.
Generic names are specified in the Food Standards Code. For example: The ingredient list could show the ingredients apple, pear and peach as either:

  • Fruit, or
  • Fruit (apple, pear, peach)

components.legend: Does your food contain any food additives?
components.label: Does your food contain any food additives?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  For example: Food colours, flavours, preservatives, sweeteners, thickeners, etc.
  </small>

components.label: Does your food contain any food additives?
HTML
components.content:
Food additives

The substance (including a vitamin or mineral) used as a food additive must be declared.
The Food Standards Code specifies how to list food additives in the ingredient list. This includes a list of class names and codes to use for specific food additives.
For example: The ingredient list would show the yellow food colouring tartrazine as either:

  • Colour (tartrazine), or
  • Colour (102)

components.legend: Does your food contain any exempt ingredients that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
components.label: Does your food contain any exempt ingredients that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
HTML
components.content:
For example:

  • A substance or food that is used as a processing aid.
  • An ingredient of a flavouring substance.
  • An ingredient such as water or alcohol, that is completely removed during the manufacture of the food.
  • Added water that forms part of broth, brine or syrup.

components.label: Does your food contain any exempt ingredients that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
HTML
components.content:
Exempt ingredients

Exempt ingredients do not need to be included in the ingredient list.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Enter ingredients in descending order of ingoing weight

components.legend: Enter each ingredient that is used to make your food in descending order of ingoing weight.
components.label: Enter each ingredient that is used to make your food in descending order of ingoing weight.
<small class="hint">  You can change the order of your ingredients using the up and down arrows. </small>
HTML
components.content:
The ingredients should be shown on a food label as:

Ingredients: {{data.IngredientData.map((data) => data.ingredient)}}

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Your label information

Congratulations! You have completed all the steps in Label Buster.

Using your responses to each question, Label Buster has generated a product sheet and an example food label.

Label Buster is a brief guide to help you understand your labelling requirements. You may choose to get advice from a labelling consultant to make sure that your label complies with the Food Standards Code.

On this page, you will find:

  • Product sheet
  • Example food label
  • Legibility requirements
  • Exemptions
  • Download or email your summary
  • Need to update your label?

Product Sheet

You can take this information to a printer or graphic designer to create a label or use your own tools/templates. When creating your food label, you must ensure you meet the legibility requirements , such as minimum type size.

Food name and description {{data.productDescription || 'no data provided'}}
Business details {{data.address || 'no data provided'}}
Ingredients Ingredients: {{data.IngredientData.map((data) => data.ingredient) || 'no data provided'}}
Weight {{data.ingredients || 'no data provided'}}
Nutrition information panel A Nutrition Information Panel must be added to your food label. The Food Standards Australia New Zealand nutrition panel calculator can help you prepare your nutrition information panel.
Statements and declarations

Contains: {{data.allergens || 'no data provided'}}
Note: Warning statements must be a minimum size of type of 3 mm. In the case of small packages, a minimum size of type of 1.5 mm is required.
Date marks Best Before: {{data.bestBefore || 'no data provided'}}
Lot identification {{data.batch || 'no data provided'}}
Storage conditions and directions for use

Storage conditions: {{data.storageConditions || 'no data provided'}}
Directions for use: {{data.directions || 'no data provided'}}

Claims

Making voluntary claims about your food is very complex and you are recommended to seek professional advice.
Please note, that making a claim on your food has other requirements not addressed in Label Buster such as additional sections in your nutritional information panel and requirements under Australian Consumer Law.

Country of origin Information on how to calculate and display mandatory country of origin can be found on the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission website.
Health star rating Information on how to calculate and display a voluntary health star rating can be found at the health star rating system website.

Example of food label

Below is an example of what your label could look like, using the information you provided in Label Buster. Label components can be placed anywhere on the label you create. They do not need to be in the specific layout shown here. They may be displayed in any order or arrangement

Product name

Product description

Storage conditions: Keep refrigerated at 1 degree to 5 degree. Shake well before opening. Store in an upright position.

Directions for use: Consume within 2 days of opening.

Best before: 05 / 04 / 2021

Lot identification: Batch 42

Ingredients: {{data.IngredientData.map((data) => data.ingredient)}}

Contains: list items

Address line one
Address line two
Address line three

Legibility requirements

All required words, statements, expressions or designs provided on a food label must be in English, be legible, and be prominent so as to contrast distinctly with the background of the label.

Information in other languages is permitted, provided it does not negate or contradict the English information.

No specific print type or size is defined for general labelling requirements, however:

  • warning statements must be in a type size of at least 3mm (or 1.5mm on small packages)
  • a print size is prescribed in the Food Standards Code for some foods where a required statement must be shown (e.g. infant formula).

Exemptions

All of the food label information needs to be included on your food label, except for:

  • Food sold in small packages
  • Food with one ingredient

There are extra requirements for:

  • Food sold from a vending machine
  • Food sold in a hamper

Your label information summary

Download your label information summary. This summary includes your product sheet and an example of what your label could look like.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
If you prefer, we can send you your self-assessment summary by providing an email address below.

Email

Depending on your email provider, personal information may be transferred outside of Australia. By providing your email address, you voluntarily agree to this transfer.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Need to update your food label?

If you would like to update details in your food label, such as different flavours or ingredients, you can go back and update your answers by clicking on the relevant step. You can then regenerate your label with these new details.
